Thomé Investigation Writing – original draft 2 b Jatuporn Wittayakun Resources Writing – review & editing 3 c Frank Roessner Conceptualization Supervision Writing – review & editing ⁎ 4 c a Institute of Chemistry, Carl von Ossietzky University Oldenburg, 26129 Oldenburg, Germany Institute of Chemistry Carl von Ossietzky University Oldenburg 26129 Oldenburg Germany Institute of Chemistry, Carl von Ossietzky University Oldenburg, 26129 Oldenburg, Germany b INEOS Phenol GmbH, 45966 Gladbeck, Germany INEOS Phenol GmbH 45966 Gladbeck Germany INEOS Phenol GmbH, 45966 Gladbeck, Germany c School of Chemistry, Institute of Science, Suranaree University of Technology, Muang, Nakhon Ratchasima, 3000 Thailand School of Chemistry, Institute of Science Suranaree University of Technology Muang, Nakhon Ratchasima 3000 Thailand School of Chemistry, Institute of Science, Suranaree University of Technology, Muang, Nakhon Ratchasima, 3000 Thailand ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 orcid: 0009-0001-7699-3921 2 orcid: 0000-0002-9544-0126 3 orcid: 0000-0002-4426-2825 4 orcid: 0000-0003-2455-0579 Graphical abstract The kinetics of the aldol condensation of n-butanal on modified mesoporous and macro-mesoporous heterogeneous catalysts was studied in the liquid phase. Applying liquid phase 1H NMR the degree of modification was determined quantitatively, in order to calculate the turnover numbers of the n-butanal conversion. The analysis of the kinetic data has shown that the reaction on primary amines follows a 1st order model, whereas on secondary amines the 2nd model gives the best correlation. Tertiary and aromatic amines were not active. Based on the kinetic measurements reaction mechanisms are proposed. The difference in the activation energies suggests that the modification process on mesoporous materials proceeds preferentially on the external surface, while on meso-macroporous materials the modification proceeds in the mesopores. Keywords Macro-mesoporous material Aldol condensation of n-butanal Quantification of grafting Kinetic of aldol condensation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction 2-Ethylhexanol is an important intermediate for the production of plasticizers, a flavor and as a fragrance and can furthermore be used as a solvent [1]. The precursor of the 2-ethylhexanol is the 2-ethylhexenal (2EH), which is produced via the aldol condensation of n-butanal in liquid phase with sodium hydroxide as a homogeneous catalyst [2]. Lee and Varma studied the biphasic aldol condensation of n-butanal catalyzed by sodium hydroxide. It was found that the reaction is to be 1st order in both n-butanal and NaOH concentration. The activation energy was 13.5 kcal/mol indicating on mass transfer limitations [3]. The substitution of the homogeneous catalyst by usage of heterogeneous catalysts is a key step in the direction of a sustainable process. Furthermore, the mass transport through the liquid-liquid interface is substituted by the adsorption of the reactant on the heterogeneous surface. Recently, it has been discovered that not only single component metal oxides but also alkali modified oxides, alkali ion exchanged zeolites, and nonoxide catalysts exhibit basic properties on the surfaces [4]. First attempts were made by Zhang et al. [5] who studied the activity of n-butanal in the aldol condensation in the dependency on the basicity. It was found that the conversion in liquid phase at 0 ∘ C changed in the order: MgO (35%) > La 2 O 3 (3.2 %) > ZrO 2 (0.9 %). Also, alkali modified basic zeolites and alumina were investigated by Tsuji et al. [2], however their activity could not compete with those of the alkaline oxides. Interestingly, they found that in the absence of acidic surface centers the Tishchenko-type cross-esterification is suppressed. In 1992 a new class of mesoporous silicas of type MCM-41 was synthesized [6]. The surface of this material consists of silanol groups which can be used as anchors for modifying agents allowing a preparation of tailor-made basic surfaces. Applying aminosiloxanes with different degrees of substitution of the nitrogen center the basicity can be adjusted. So, the conversion of n-butanal on mesoporous FSM-16 modified with secondary amines was reported [7]. Collier et al. [8] used MCM-41 modified with 4-aminobutyltriethoxysilane (AB). They claimed that the reaction proceeds via a cooperative mechanism involving adjacent surface silanol groups. Currently, the focus is also directed towards the application of hierarchical structured materials. According to the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) pores are classified by pore diameter (d): (i) micropores d < 2 nm; (ii) mesopores 2 > d > 50 nm and (iii) macropores with d > 50 nm [9]. So micro-mesoporous and micro-macroporous materials are described in the literature [10]. Recently, on the synthesis of meso-macroporous silica was reported by Thomé et al. [11]. These modified materials seem to be suitable for the improvement of mass transport phenomena, especially for the usage in the liquid phase. The aim of the present work is to study the kinetics of the aldol condensation of n-butanal on porous materials modified with amino groups to identify the influence of the nature of primary and secondary different amines. Note, as shown previously tertiary and aromatic amines are not active in the reaction [12]. Furthermore, the meso-macroporous system will be used to determine the rate determining step in the liquid phase reaction. 2 Experimental details Synthesis of the MCM-41 The MCM-41 was synthesized as described by Zhao et al. [13]. 7.3 g (20 mmol) cetyltrimethylammoniumbromide (CTAB, 96 %, Fluka) was dissolved in 180 mL water. After that, 4.6 mL (2.6 g, 57.9 mmol) of a 70 % ethylamine solution in water (Merck, Germany) was added to adjust the pH value. Then, 22.1 mL (20.8 g, 100 mmol) tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS, 99 %, Wacker Germany) was added and the mixture was stirred for 2 h at 30 ∘ C. The reaction mixture was filled into a PTFE-lined autoclave and heated to 100 ∘ C for 48 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the mixture was filtered and washed with water and ethanol (99 % denatured with Toluene, Sigma Aldrich). The MCM-41 was calcined at 550 ∘ C for 8 h in air to remove the template. Synthesis of the macro-mesoporous MCM-41 The macro-mesoporous MCM-41 was synthesized as described by Thomé [11]. Prior to the addition of CTAB 10 g of yeast was suspended in the water and stirred for 30 mins at 30 ∘ C. The further procedure was as described above. Modification The calcined materials were dried for 24 h at 50 ∘ C and then suspended in toluene (50 mL per 1 g of sample)(99.5 %, VWR Chemicals). The suspension was heated to 80 ° C. The modifier (see Table 1 , all: abcr GmbH) was added dropwise (0.9 mmol per gram of material). The mixture was stirred for 3 h. The solid was filtered off, washed with ethanol and dried at 50 ∘ C for 16 h. The resulting materials were denominated as follows: [modifier] - [host] Where: [modifier] - nature of modifier: 4-aminobutyltriethoxysilane (AB) 3-aminopropyldimethylethoxysilane (APDM) N-methylaminopropyltrimethoxysilane (MAP). and [host] - pore structure: mesoporous (M) macro-mesoporous (MM). 3 Characterization Pore characteristics Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was conducted on a Hitachi S-3200N. The samples were sputtered with a 15 nm gold layer prior to microscopy. Low temperature nitrogen adsorption isotherms of freshly calcined samples (each sample ∼ 100 mg) were recorded at 77 K using a Micromeritics ASAP2060. For the calculation of Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surfaces the linear region between p/p 0 = 0.04–0.24 was used. For the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution desorption branches were employed using Kruk-Jaroniec-Sayari (KJS) t-curve and correction factors. Determination of the degree of modification The degree of modification was determined by a method proposed by Thomé et al. [14]. Liquid-phase NMR measurements were carried out using a Bruker 300 instrument. Samples were measured using an auto sampler as well as an auto-shim and an auto-lock function. 1 H nuclei were measured at 300 MHz. In short, a defined amount of the modified MCM-41 catalyst was dissolved in a mixture of NaOD (NaOD/D 2 O 30 wt% in D 2 O, Sigma Aldrich) and D 2 O (99.9 %, deutero). A defined amount of acetic anhydride was added and the formed acetate was used as an internal standard. Kinetic measurements The aldol reaction was performed in 7 mL septum sealed vials. Into these 200 mg of the catalyst was added and suspended in 4.2 mL of tetrahydrofurane (THF, 99.99 %, stabilized with 0.025 % butyrhydroxytoluene), Fisher Chemicals) as a solvent. THF was chosen as solubility aid to avoid phase separation caused by formed water. The vials were placed in an orbital shaker and heated to the indicated reaction temperature. The reaction was started by adding 2.1 mL of n-butanal (note that the n-butanal was stabilized with 1 % H 2 O and 0.1 % butyrhydroxytoluene (BHT), 99 %, Fluka). After defined time intervals, 0.2 mL samples of the mixture were withdrawn with a syringe. The samples were filled into GC vials after passing a syringe filter to remove remaining traces of the catalyst. The samples were diluted with 1 mL of diethyl ether (99.5 %, stabilized with BHT, Sigma Aldrich) and analyzed on a gas chromatograph HP 5890 series II equipped with a 51 m CP-Wax 52 CB column. Quantitative evaluation The amount of substance n* of 2-ethylhex-2-enal (2EH), 2-ethyl-3-hydroxyhexanal (2E3HH) and n-butanal obtained via GC analysis were divided by the degree of modification multiplied with the mass of catalyst to get a normalized amount of substance n. Hereby the amount of substance is therefore normalized to the degree of modification and the mass of the catalyst to provide a better comparability between the catalysts. The normalized amount of substance n was calculated according to Eq. (1): (1) n = n * ( d · m ) with: n - normalized amount of substance (mmol/mmol) n * - amount of substance (mmol/mmol) d - degree of modification (mmol/g) m - mass of catalyst (g) Eq. (2) was used for 1st order reactions: (2) ln ( c 0 c t ) = k · t Eq. (3) was used as a general approach to determine the higher reaction orders: (3) 1 ( n − 1 ) · ( 1 c t ( n − 1 ) − 1 c 0 ( n − 1 ) ) = k · t with: n - reaction order t - time (min) c t - concentration at the time t normalized to the degree of modification (mol/L) c 0 - concentration at the time 0 normalized to the degree of modification (mol/L) k - reaction rate constant ((L/mol) ( n − 1 ) · 1/min) The activation energy was calculated using the linearized Arrhenius Eq. (4): (4) ln k = − E A R · 1 T + ln A with: E A - activation energy (J/mol) R - universal gas constant (8.314 kJ/(mol · K)) T - temperature (K) A - pre-exponential factor 4 Results and discussion In Fig. 1 (left) the yields of the products are plotted in dependence on the temperature for the six different catalysts. For all temperatures the formation of both aldol products is observed. The yield of the condensation product (2EH) is increasing with the temperature for all catalysts. On the other hand, the temperature dependence of the yield for the adduct (2E3HH) is not well pronounced. Considering the influence of the pore structure (mesoporous vs. macro-mesoporous) no consistent dependency can be observed. That is, AB-MM shows a higher conversion than AB-M but MAP-MM has a lower conversion than MAP-M. Since the reaction is expected to take place at the basic centers the yield should be correlated with the actual amount of these centers instead of the mass of catalyst. The determination of accessible single sites in solids is very difficult. Recently, an experimental approach for the quantitative determination of organic moieties in silica materials, using liquid NMR spectroscopy, was published by Thomé et al. [14]. Despite that no information about the accessibility of the active centers is provided, a precise determination of the overall content is possible (Table 2 ). As described above in Eq. (1) the catalytic results (Fig. 1 left) were normalized with the degree of modification determined by liquid phase NMR spectroscopy (Table 2). The normalized values are depicted in Fig. 1 on the right side. A strong influence of the pore structure and dimensions becomes apparent. For all modifiers the conversion on macro-mesoporous materials (AB-MM, APDM-MM, MAP-MM) is higher than on mesoporous materials (AB-M, APDM-M, MAP-M). As expected, the temperature dependency is not affected by the normalization. Pore Properties The pore systems were characterized by low temperature nitrogen adsorption (BET). Both the mesoporous, as well as the macro-mesoporous catalysts show well defined mesopores with a narrow pore size distribution (Fig. 2 ). The slightly lower pore diameter of APDM-MM compared to APDM-M lets assume, that the location of the modifier is different for both materials. Probably, the modifier is grafted preferentially inhomogeneously in the mesopores (broader pore size districbution), whereas for APDM-M the location on the external surface seems to be preferred, affecting the pore size to a lower extend. The data of mercury porosimetry indicates the presence of macro-pores in the macro-mesoporous material in the range of the cell size of the used yeast cells as described previously [11]. The SEM images shown in Fig. 3 support this expected macroporosity by displaying various voids compared to the more densely packed mesoporous materials. The size of the voids is in good agreement with the above-mentioned cell size. Since the as-prepared materials were calcined, only negligible amounts of residue from yeast decomposition products are expected. 5 Conversion and yield of the different catalysts Conversion of n-butanal The overall conversion of n-butanal at 61 ∘ C for the different catalysts is depicted in Fig. 4 . A strong increase of the conversion within the initial 100 min is characteristic for all catalysts. Afterwards, the curves of conversion flatten. A direct comparison reveals a higher conversion for the macro-mesoporous (MM, 5A) catalysts compared to the mesoporous (M, 5B) materials. Additionally, the MAP catalysts show a significantly higher activity and therefore higher conversion than the AB and APDM catalysts independently from the pore structure. An identical sequence sec. > prim. > > tert. for MCMs (Xie et al. [15]) and for SBA-15 (Kubota et al. [16]) modified with amines was reported for the aldol condensation of nitrobenzaldehyde with acetone. To get more detailed insight into the mechanism of the reaction the selectivity was plotted against the conversion (Fig. 5 ). Independently from the pore structure of the catalyst and the temperature the selectivity of 2E3HH decreases with a higher conversion whereas the selectivity of 2EH increases concurrently. This allows to conclude that 2E3HH is the primary product of the reaction which is then converted to 2EH (secondary product). This general behavior was observed for all studied catalysts. The comparison of primary (AB) and secondary amines (MAP) is depicted on the right side of Fig. 5. Surprisingly the corresponding curves for 2E3HH and 2EH show a different behavior. The ratio 2E3HH:2EH = 1:1 is observed at X = 35 % for the AB modified catalysts and at X = 52 % for the MAP modified catalysts. Furthermore, the slope of these curves differs between primary and secondary amine. The fact, that all data of the same degree of substitution of the amine fits into one curve, shows that the same mechanism applies independently from temperature and pore structure. On the other hand, deviations from this behavior indicate different mechanisms, i.e. the reaction mechanism on primary and secondary amines must be different. Note, that the tertiary and aromatic amines are not active in the aldol condensation of n-butanal [12]. This trend could correlate either with the basicity of amines in aqueous solution or with the presence of hydrogen atoms bound to the nitrogen atom. 5.1 Kinetic analysis Kinetic analysis of the reaction was done to gain more insight into the reaction mechanism. It was found that the typical formal plots assuming a first or second order reaction do not follow the expected linear trend for the MAP modified catalysts. A sharp switch in slope of the kinetic curve after approximately 20 min was observed indicating a change of rate limiting steps. (This behavior was observed for all studied MAP-samples.) Thus, in this work only the initial 20 min of the reaction were considered for the calculation of the rate constant k (for the MAP catalysts).The integral method was used as described above. For catalysts modified with primary amines (AB and APDM) the best fit of the data results in a reaction order of 1.0. Although the correlation factor of APDM-MM at 61 ∘ C and APDM-M at 25 ∘ C is low, it is still higher than for other reaction orders (see Table 3 ). In case of the MAP modified structures a tendency to deviate from the 1st order can be seen. This could be an indication that the reaction mechanism on secondary amines differs from those of primary ones. Presumably the chemical reaction is the rate determining step in the initial period, due to the high concentration of the reactants. This effect could be explained by several causes: (i) diffusion limitations of products and feed molecules, (ii) poisoning of the reactive centers by the formed water, (iii) consecutive reactions resulting in higher molecular compounds, e.g. the formation of Tishchenko type products. Furthermore, it should be considered that the catalyst could be potentially inhibited in the base medium. Interestingly, the reaction order seems to vary around 1.0 and 2.0. Based on these results for the calculation of the activation energy a reaction order of 1.0 for the catalysts modified with primary and 2.0 for secondary amines was assumed. As shown in Table 4 the activation energy for macro-mesoporous catalysts is higher than for the mesoporous catalysts. Generally the activation energies are of the same order of magnitude as reported by Collier et al. [8] for the aldol condensation on MCM-41 modified with (4-Aminobutyl)triethoxysilane. Since the values for the mesoporous materials are very close to the activation energy of diffusion, a possible explanation could be that the reaction takes place preferentially at the external surface. In other words the majority of the modifiers are on the external surface. Due to the presence of macropores in the macro-mesoporous material the transport of the modifier during modification could be enhanced. Consequently, the modifiers should be located inside the mesopores. This would have an influence on the rate determining step of the aldol reaction. A similar influence of diffusion and adsorption of tocopherol on mesoporous MCM-41 and SBA-15 was observed by Karpov et al. [17]. Reaction mechanism The kinetic analysis indicates a relation between the basicity and the catalytic activity of the amines. Typically, the basicity of amines in aqueous solutions is described as the highest for secondary amines (e.g. diethyl amine pKa = 11.0), followed by primary (e.g. ethyl amine pKa = 10.7), tertiary (e.g. triethyl amine pKa = 10.56) and aromatic amines (e.g. pyridine pKa = 5.2) [18]. A similar sequence was described above for grafted amines on MCM-41 with various pore architecture. As reported previously, grafted tertiary and aromatic amines are not active in the aldol-condensation of n-butanal. Therefore, they were not considered in this study [12]. Proposed mechanism As described above the reaction rate differs for the conversion of n-butanal on materials modified with primary and secondary amines, respectively. This should also be reflected in the reaction mechanism. Primary amines: In a previous work [12] it was shown that at least one hydrogen atom bonded to the nitrogen atom is needed to initialize the aldol reaction. The initial step should be the condensation of the carbonyl group of n-butanal X1 with the amine group X2 to form an imine X3 (Fig. 6 ). Similar findings were reported for the Knvenagel reaction on OMS modified with primary amines [19]. This should be the rate determining step since the analysis of the formal kinetic has shown a reaction of 1st order (Table 3). The second step is the addition of a molecule of n-butanal X1 to the surface bonded imine X3. This reaction could proceed both via addition of the β -H atom of the n-butanal X1 to the double bond of the imine X3 or by the rearrangement of the double bonds of the keto-enol-tautomer X4 and the imine X3. The shift of the remaining β -H atom forms the 2-ethylhex-2-enal X5 (2EH) and restores the primary amine X2 on the catalyst surface. This mechanism is in agreement with the product distribution as shown in Fig. 1 (right). However, the formation of 2-ethyl-3-hydroxyhexanal X6 (2E3HH) indicates on a parallel mechanism similar to the one described for the secondary amines (see below). In principle, the reaction path via enamine is also possible, however the imine is thermodynamically preferred. Secondary amines: The primary step should be the reaction of n-butanal X1 with a surface bonded secondary amine X7 resulting in the formation of enamine X8 (Fig. 7). The enamine X8 deprotonates a second n-butanal molecule X1 giving an enolate ion X9. The enolate can further attack another n-butanal molecule X1 thus leading to the dimer X10 stabilized by the positive charge of the protonated enamine X11. At this stage two different reaction paths are open: (i) Via an intramolecular protonation the negative charge moves from the oxygen to the tertiary carbon atom in alpha position to the carbonyl group. The formed hydroxyl group abstracts the hydrogen atom from the protonated enamine X11 accompanied by the elimination of water resulting in the desorbed 2-ethylhex-2-enal (aldol condensate) X12 . (ii) Alternatively, an intermolecular proton transfer from X11 gives 2-ethyl-3-hydroxyhexanal (aldol adduct) X6 and the surface bonded enamine X8. According to the kinetic analysis the reaction order was 2, i.e. the reaction between the enolate and a free n-butanal molecule should be the rate determining step. Independently from the structure of the MCM-41, the ratio of 2E3HH to 2EH strongly depends on the temperature (see Fig. 1 right). So, for MAP-MM it changes from 3:1 to 1:4 at 25 ∘ C and 61 ∘ C. 6 Conclusion The influence of the structure of meso- and meso-macroporous silicas on the activity in the aldol condensation of n-butanal was studied. The surface was modified by grafting with primary and secondary aminoalkylsiloxanes. Their amount was determined by liquid phase 1H-NMR spectroscopy. This allowed the calculation of real turnover numbers in the condensation of n-butanal. At temperatures T = 25 ∘ C the mesoporous materials showed a higher activity than the macro-mesoporous materials. With increasing temperature this sequence has changed. Furthermore, secondary amines are more active than primary ones. Based on the kinetic data the best fit for primary and secondary amines was obtained for a reaction of 1 and 2, respectively. On surface bonded secondary amines the route via an enamine intermediate is favored, whereas on primary amines the imine intermediate seems to be preferred. The kinetic analysis allows to assume that this can be related to the non-uniform distribution of the active centers, i.e. in mesoporous materials the modifier should be located preferentially on the external surface whereas in the meso-macroporous materials it is located preferentially in the mesopores as shown by the different values in the activation energy and the size of the mesopores after grafting. coredata.dc:description: The kinetics of the aldol condensation of n-butanal on modified mesoporous and macro-mesoporous heterogeneous catalysts was studied in the liquid phase. Applying liquid phase 1H NMR the degree of modification was determined quantitatively, in order to calculate the turnover numbers of the n-butanal conversion. The analysis of the kinetic data has shown that the reaction on primary amines follows a 1st order model, whereas on secondary amines the 2nd model gives the best correlation. Tertiary and aromatic amines were not active. Based on the kinetic measurements reaction mechanisms are proposed. The difference in the activation energies suggests that the modification process on mesoporous materials proceeds preferentially on the external surface, while on meso-macroporous materials the modification proceeds in the mesopores.
coredata.dc:title: Kinetic investigation of the aldol condensation of n-butanal on mesoporous and macro-mesoporous heterogeneous catalysts
